Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Mobile Content Sharing Networks:Theory to Implementation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The last few years have witnessed an explosive growth in the popularity and capabilities of mobile handheld devices such as smart-phones, tablets, and laptops. The rapidly expanding computational power of these portable devices has enabled their users to access, process, and share content anytime, anywhere. However, these devices have already put significant stress on many of today's 3G/4G cellular networks, which, if left unaddressed, will result in increasingly poor quality-of-service and user experience in the future.

To address this problem, the project investigates how to exploit the key attributes of mobile content sharing environments to dramatically increase network performance. Preliminary studies show that jointly utilizing the wireless channel and mobility can yield greater gains than even the sum of exploiting mobility and the channel independently. In this case, the whole is greater than the sum of its parts! Thus, the main focus of this research is to (i) develop the analytical foundation for double opportunism - i.e., joint exploitation of the wireless channel and mobility-considering the practical realities of the wireless environment for content distribution networks; (ii) develop low-complexity algorithms, heuristics, and distributed protocols that are provably efficient; (iii) investigate the impact of imperfect knowledge on performance; (iv) validate the results via testbed deployment.

The project is expected to lead to fundamental breakthroughs in the design and performance of wireless networks for content sharing. The algorithms and protocols developed by exploiting double opportunism, and the theories underlying them, will have a significant impact on the wireless industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project is to understand at a fundamental level how mobile wireless networks can be designed in a practical heterogeneous setting. The specific objectives are to design and develop efficient dissemination and sharing protocols, energy-­efficient algorithms and cross-­layer optimization for various wireless network settings, including mobile and heterogeneous systems. Our approach has been to be able to jointly exploit and explore opportunities such as mobility, fading, and user/traffic predictability to make the overall system more efficient.  

This multi-university highly collaborative project produced several key outcomes. They can be summarized across two meta-thrusts: (1) Theoretical foundation development and algorithm design: (a) We found that double-opportunities, i.e.  joint exploitation of the wireless channel and mobility, could result in substantial gains not only in terms of throughput but also in terms of fairness.  (b) We were the first researchers to develop a distributed Newton’s method for wireless networks. We developed a second-order joint congestion control and routing optimization framework that offers utility-optimality, queue-stability, fast convergence, and low delays. The advantage of such an approach is that overcomes the difficulties in dynamic network settings where mobile nodes can arrive and leave before traditional algorithms can converge to good operating points.  (c) We developed a new paradigm for providing probabilistic guarantees on the time of spread rather than use the traditional average metric, as it provides a much better understanding of the spread in mobile networks, and hence could be used to design improved methods devise accelerated methods for distributing data. (d) For video nodes, we developed a novel way of utilizing helper nodes to minimize the pressure on the central servers for video streaming applications. We formulate the problem as a linear programming using joint inter- and intra- layer network coding. Our solution can also be implemented in a distributed manner. We show how our method can be extended to the case of wireless live streaming, in which a set of videos is broadcasted. (2) Protocol and system development for mobile content sharing: (a) We designed and developed a chained gateway for long-range wireless networks.  It consists of a group of interlinked routers running the gateway protocol for node failure amortization across the long stretching router chain. (b) We designed a new type of incentive-driven and privacy-preserving systems for large-scale message dissemination in mobile networks. Our experiments show that our system is efficient in peer-to-peer message distribution and capable of massive deployment. (c) We developed a privacy-preserving machine learning framework for a crowd of smart devices, which can solve a wide range of learning problems for crowd-sensing data with differential privacy guarantees.  

The project produced tens of journal and conference publications, many involving faculty and student participants from collaborating universities. The results have been published on http://newslab.ece.ohio-state.edu/funded_projects/1065136.html. The project also provided research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, including students from underrepresented groups.
